question: Question_06
statement:
A swimming pool is 10 m wide and 20 m long and its bottom is an inclined
plane, the shallow end having depth 1 m and the deep end 2 m. If the
pool is full of water, find the hydrostatic force, in Newtons (N), on
the long vertical side of the pool that is shaded in the diagram below.
For acceleration due to gravity use the value $g = 9.8\, m/s^2$ and for
the density of water use the value $\rho = 1000\, kg/m^3$.

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{MATH_101_April_2010_Question_6_pic.png}
\caption{MATH\_101\_April\_2010\_Question\_6\_pic.png}
\end{figure}
sols:
\emph{There is a certain ambiguity to how the diagram presents this
problem. While it talks of a standard swimming pool with an inclined
plane along the bottom, the diagram looks as if the top-side is
inclined. Therefore we will present a solution where the bottom is flat
and the top side is inclined and another solution where the top is flat
and the bottom side is inclined. The approach to both problems is the
same but the numerical results will differ.}

\textbf{Top Inclined, Bottom Flat:}

Create a diagram (like that to the right) that just illustrates the side
of pool we are interested in
\href{file:Math101Apr20106.png}{right\textbar{}500px\textbar{}thumbnail}.
We will use the standard coordinate system of $x$ representing the
horizontal direction and $y$ representing the vertical direction.

Notice we can divide the figure into a rectangular portion and a
triangular portion which in the diagram is separated by a dashed line.
Since this triangular portion is actually a right triangle we can
determine the missing size $z$ to be

\begin{align*}z=\sqrt{20^2-1^2}=\sqrt{399}.\end{align*}

Now we are interested in determining the hydrostatic force that is
exerted on this pool wall. From the hint we know this depends on the
pressure which we can write as,

\begin{align*}\displaystyle{}P=\rho{}g(2-y)\end{align*}

where we take $y=0$ to be the bottom of the diagram. Notice that because
of this definition of y, the depth, h, as defined in the hint is then
actually h=2-y since the top of the surface is at y=2. We see that
depending where we are along the pool side, we will exert a different
pressure and therefore a different force. Since the pressure depends on
$y$, let's consider a very small rectangle of height $\textrm{d}y$ and
length, $L$. The small amount of force exerted on this rectangle of area
$\textrm{d}A$ is,

\begin{align*}\displaystyle{}\textrm{d}F=P\textrm{d}A=\rho{}g(2-y)Ldy.\end{align*}

Therefore the total amount of force exerted will be the sum of the
little amounts of force on each rectangle as we go from height $y=0$ to
height $y=2$. However, we have to be careful, because as we climb up the
height of the pool side, the length of the small rectangles depend on
our height $y$ due to the pool getting narrower in the triangular
region. We will then break up the problem into computing the total force
on the rectangular portion, $F_1$ and the total force on the triangular
portion, $F_2$. In the end the total force will be, $F=F_1+F_2$.

\textbf{Rectangular Portion}:

In this region, for any given height, $y$, the length is a constant and
in fact we already computed it,

\begin{align*}L=\sqrt{399}.\end{align*}

Therefore, for this region we have that for every little rectangle,

\begin{align*}\displaystyle\textrm{d}F_1=\rho{g}\sqrt{399}(2-y)\textrm{d}y.\end{align*}

In order to add up the contributions from all the small rectangles we
turn to integration,

\begin{align*}
F_1=\int\textrm{d}F_1&=\int_0^1\rho{g}\sqrt{399}(2-y)\textrm{d}y\\
&=\rho{g}\sqrt{399}\left.\left(2y-\frac{y^2}{2}\right)\right|_{0}^1\\
&=\frac{3\rho{g}\sqrt{399}}{2}.\end{align*}

The limits of integration can be seen from the diagram since the
rectangular region starts at the bottom and goes up 1m.

\textbf{Triangular Portion}:

This region is slightly more tricky to compute because the length
changes with the height. The first thing we need to do is figure out a
function for the slanted side of the triangle in terms of $x$ and $y$.
We see that it is a line so it will be of the form $y=mx+b$ with $m$ the
slope and $b$ the y-intercept. We know that when the height is 1, we are
at the left edge of the diagram which we will denote $x=0$. When the
height is 2, we are at the right edge of the diagram which we know is

\begin{align*}x=\sqrt{399}.\end{align*}

Therefore we get that the slope is

\begin{align*}m=\frac{2-1}{\sqrt{399}-0}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{399}}\end{align*}

and the y-intercept occurs when $x=0$ so $b=1$. Therefore, the slanted
edge of the triangle is given by,

\begin{align*}y=\frac{1}{\sqrt{399}}x+1.\end{align*}

Now at any height, the length of our small rectangle will start at the
slant edge,

\begin{align*}x=\sqrt{399}(y-1)\end{align*}

and extend to the right edge of the diagram at $x=\sqrt{399}$. Therefore
we have that the length at any given height $y$, is

\begin{align*}L(y)=\sqrt{399}-\sqrt{399}(y-1)=\sqrt{399}(2-y).\end{align*}

The small amount of force on any rectangle in this region is,

\begin{align*}\textrm{d}F_2=P\textrm{d}A=\rho{g}yL\textrm{d}y=\rho{g}\sqrt{399}(2-y)(2-y)\textrm{d}y.\end{align*}

In order to get the total force on the triangular region we integrate
all these little $\textrm{d}F_2$ over every height in the triangular
region. This region starts at $y=1$ and ends at $y=2$. Therefore these
are our lower and upper limits of integration respectively. We get for
our total force in this region,

\begin{align*}
F_2=\int\textrm{d}F_2&=\int_1^2\rho{g}\sqrt{399}(2-y)^2\textrm{d}y\\
&=\rho{g}\sqrt{399}\int_1^2(y^2-4y+4)\textrm{d}y\\
&=\rho{g}\sqrt{399}\left(\frac{y^3}{3}-2y^2+4y\right)_{1}^2\\
&=\frac{1}{3}\rho{g}\sqrt{399}.\end{align*}

We can now compute the total force as,

\begin{align*}F=F_1+F_2=\rho{g}\sqrt{399}\left(\frac{3}{2}+\frac{1}{3}\right)=\frac{11}{6}\rho{g}\sqrt{399}\end{align*}

which using the numbers provided in the question, $\rho=1000$ and
$g=9.8$, we get,

\begin{align*}F\approx{}358883.9N\end{align*}

which is a very large force but not unsurprising considering the power
that water has.

\textbf{Caution!!}

You may be tempted to want to set up an integral with $x$ instead of
$y$, i.e. a diagram that looks like that to the right
\href{file:Math101Apr20106false.png}{right\textbar{}500px\textbar{}thumbnail}.

The problem is that, as we mentioned above, the pressure is a function
of height. Based on this formulation and this diagram, the small
rectangles take every height value from the base of the rectangle to the
slanted edge and so the pressure varies along the whole length of the
rectangle. You may think that a solution to this problem is to take your
rectangle of height, $L$ and width $\textrm{d}x$ and splice it up into
even \textbf{smaller} rectangles of say height $\textrm{d}y$ and width
$\textrm{d}x$. You then would have an integration problem on your small
rectangle from the diagram and then another integration problem as you
vary $x$ and look at other small rectangles. This solution technique is
very valid and is known as double integration, something that will be
covered in more advanced courses.

\emph{There is a certain ambiguity to how the diagram presents this
problem. While it talks of a standard swimming pool with an inclined
plane along the bottom, the diagram looks as if the top-side is
inclined. Therefore we will present a solution where the bottom is flat
and the top side is inclined and another solution where the top is flat
and the bottom side is inclined. The approach to both problems is the
same but the numerical results will differ.}

\textbf{Top Flat, Bottom Inclined:}

Create a diagram (like that to the right) that just illustrates the side
of pool we are interested in
\href{file:Math101Apr20106alt.png}{right\textbar{}500px\textbar{}thumbnail}.
We will use the standard coordinate system of $x$ representing the
horizontal direction and $y$ representing the vertical direction.

Notice we can divide the figure into a rectangular portion and a
triangular portion which in the diagram is separated by a dashed line.
Now we are interested in determining the hydrostatic force that is
exerted on this pool wall. From the hint we know this depends on the
pressure which we can write as,

\begin{align*}\displaystyle{}P=\rho{}g(2-y)\end{align*}

where we take $y=0$ to be the bottom of the diagram. Because of this
choice for y, we have that the depth, h, as defined in the hint is
actually h=2-y which is why that shows up in the hydrostatic pressure.
We see that depending where we are along the pool side, we will exert a
different pressure and therefore a different force. Since the pressure
depends on the height, $y$, let's consider a very small rectangle of
height $\textrm{d}y$ and length, $L$. The small amount of force exerted
on this rectangle of area $\textrm{d}A$ is,

\begin{align*}\displaystyle{}\textrm{d}F=P\textrm{d}A=\rho{}g(2-y)Ldy.\end{align*}

Therefore the total amount of force exerted will be the sum of the
little amounts of force on each rectangle as we go from height $y=0$ to
height $y=2$. However, we have to be careful, because as we climb up the
height of the pool side, the length of the small rectangles depend on
our height $y$ due to the pool getting narrower in the triangular
region. We will then break up the problem into computing the total force
on the rectangular portion, $F_1$ and the total force on the triangular
portion, $F_2$. In the end the total force will be, $F=F_1+F_2$.

\textbf{Rectangular Portion}:

In this region, for any given height, $y$, the length is a constant and
in fact it is the length of the pool,

\begin{align*}L=20.\end{align*}

Therefore, for this region we have that for every little rectangle,

\begin{align*}\displaystyle\textrm{d}F_1=\rho{g}20(2-y)\textrm{d}y.\end{align*}

In order to add up the contributions from all the small rectangles we
turn to integration,

\begin{align*}
F_1=\int\textrm{d}F_1&=\int_1^2\rho{g}20(2-y)\textrm{d}y\\
&=\rho{g}20\left.\left(2y-\frac{y^2}{2}\right)\right|_{1}^2\\
&=\frac{\rho{g}20}{2}=10\rho{g}.\end{align*}

The limits of integration can be seen from the diagram since the
rectangular region starts at $y=1$ and goes to the top of the pool at
$y=2$.

\textbf{Triangular Portion}:

This region is slightly more tricky to compute because the length
changes with the height. The first thing we need to do is figure out a
function for the slanted side of the triangle in terms of $x$ and $y$.
We see that it is a line so it will be of the form $y=mx+b$ with $m$ the
slope and $b$ the y-intercept. We know that when the height is 1, we are
at the left edge of the diagram which we will denote $x=0$. When the
height is 0, we are at the right edge of the diagram which we know is
$x=20$.

Therefore we get that the slope is

\begin{align*}m=\frac{0-1}{20-0}=-\frac{1}{20}\end{align*}

and the y-intercept occurs when $x=0$ so $b=1$. Therefore, the slanted
edge of the triangle is given by,

\begin{align*}y=-\frac{1}{20}x+1.\end{align*}

Now at any height, the length of our small rectangle will start at the
slant edge,

\begin{align*}\displaystyle{}x=-20(y-1)\end{align*}

and extend to the right edge of the diagram at $x=20$. Therefore we have
that the length at any given height $y$, is

\begin{align*}\displaystyle{}L(y)=20-(-20(y-1))=20y.\end{align*}

The small amount of force on any rectangle in this region is,

\begin{align*}\displaystyle{}\textrm{d}F_2=P\textrm{d}A=\rho{g}(2-y)L\textrm{d}y=\rho{g}20(2-y)y\textrm{d}y.\end{align*}

In order to get the total force on the triangular region we integrate
all these little $\textrm{d}F_2$ over every height in the triangular
region. This region starts at $y=0$ and ends at $y=1$. Therefore these
are our lower and upper limits of integration respectively. We get for
our total force in this region,

\begin{align*}
F_2=\int\textrm{d}F_2&=\int_0^1\rho{g}20(2y-y^2)\textrm{d}y\\
&=\rho{g}20\left.\left(y^2-\frac{y^3}{3}\right)\right|_{0}^1\\
&=\frac{40}{3}\rho{g}.\end{align*}

We can now compute the total force as,

\begin{align*}F=F_1+F_2=\rho{g}\left(10+\frac{40}{3}\right)=\frac{70}{3}\rho{g}\end{align*}

which using the numbers provided in the question, $\rho=1000$ and
$g=9.8$, we get,

\begin{align*}F\approx{}228666.7N\end{align*}

which is a very large force but not unsurprising considering the power
that water has.

\textbf{Caution!!}

You may be tempted to want to set up an integral with $x$ instead of
$y$, i.e. a diagram that looks like that to the right
\href{file:Math101Apr20106falsealt.png}{right\textbar{}500px\textbar{}thumbnail}.

The problem is that, as we mentioned above, the pressure is a function
of height. Based on this formulation and this diagram, the small
rectangles take every height value from the base of the rectangle to the
slanted edge and so the pressure varies along the whole length of the
rectangle. You may think that a solution to this problem is to take your
rectangle of height, $L$ and width $\textrm{d}x$ and splice it up into
even \textbf{smaller} rectangles of say height $\textrm{d}y$ and width
$\textrm{d}x$. You then would have an integration problem on your small
rectangle from the diagram and then another integration problem as you
vary $x$ and look at other small rectangles. This solution technique is
very valid and is known as double integration, something that will be
covered in more advanced courses.
hints:
Recall that the hydrostatic force along any surface is the hydrostatic
pressure multiplied by the area of that surface, $F=PA$. However,
\textbf{be careful} since the pressure is different at each point on the
surface; how can we relate our equation for force to integration?

Recall that the hydrostatic pressure at a depth h measured from the top
of a surface is given by,

\begin{align*}\displaystyle{}P=\rho{g}h\end{align*}

where $\rho$ is the density of the substance exerting the force (water
in this case) and $g$ is the acceleration due to gravity.
